user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_MutSemTake:
```c
int32 OS_MutSemTake(osal_id_t sem_id)
{
    OS_mutex_internal_record_t *mutex;
    OS_object_token_t           token;
    int32                       return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        mutex = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_mutex_table, token);

        return_code = OS_MutSemTake_Impl(&token);
        if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
        {
            /* Always set the owner if OS_MutSemTake_Impl() returned success */
            mutex->last_owner = OS_TaskGetId();
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_MutSemTake:
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char      obj_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t last_owner;
} OS_mutex_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_mutex_internal_record_t OS_mutex_table[LOCAL_NUM_OBJECTS]
...
int32 OS_MutSemTake_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                              status;
    OS_impl_mutex_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_mutex_table, *token);

    /*
    ** Lock the mutex
    */
    status = pthread_mutex_lock(&(impl->id));
    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
osal_id_t OS_TaskGetId(void)
{
    osal_id_t task_id;

    task_id = OS_TaskGetId_Impl();

    return task_id;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no usages of compiler language extensions in the provided code. Specifically:

- No compiler-specific keywords or constructs are present (for example: __attribute__, __extension__, typeof, __asm__, statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, or other vendor-specific builtin extensions).
- The OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro uses only standard C operators (&, array indexing) and a macro parameter; calling it with a variable (token) or with an expression (*token) results in &token or &(*token), both standard C and not compiler extensions.
- pthread_mutex_lock and related pthread usage are POSIX API calls, not language/compiler extensions, and their use does not violate the ‘‘no language extensions’’ criterion.
- Typedefs (int32, osal_id_t) and macro constants (OS_SUCCESS) are standard C features.

Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied code that appear to rely on compiler-specific language extensions and nothing needs to be flagged for further investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
